dt: {bc}to restrict the movement of by bonds or obstacles {bc}{sx|impede||}

dt.t: pitching … violently in the seaway, {wi}hampered{/wi} by her heavy tow

dt: {bc}to moderate or limit the effect or full exercise of {bc}{sx|curb||}, {sx|restrain||}
{bc}to interfere with {bc}to impede the natural activity of {bc}{sx|encumber||}

pt: {sc}hamper{/sc} {sc}trammel{/sc} {sc}clog{/sc} {sc}fetter{/sc} {sc}shackle{/sc} {sc}manacle{/sc} mean to hinder or impede in moving, progressing, or acting. {sc}hamper{/sc} may imply the effect of any impeding or restraining influence.

pt.t: {it}hampered{/it} the investigation by refusing to cooperate

pt: {sc}trammel{/sc} suggests entangling by or confining within a net.
{sc}clog{/sc} usually implies a slowing by something extraneous or encumbering.

pt.t: a court system {it}clogged{/it} by frivolous suits

pt: {sc}fetter{/sc} suggests a restraining so severe that freedom to move or progress is almost lost.

pt.t: a nation {it}fettered{/it} by an antiquated class system

pt: {sc}shackle{/sc} and {sc}manacle{/sc} are stronger than {sc}fetter{/sc} and suggest total loss of freedom.

shortdef: to restrict the movement of by bonds or obstacles : impede
to interfere with the operation of : disrupt
to moderate or limit the effect or full exercise of : curb, restrain

dt: {bc}a large basket usually with a cover for packing, storing, or transporting articles (such as food or laundry)

et: Middle English {it}hamper, hanaper{/it}, literally, case to hold goblets, from Anglo-French {it}hanaper{/it}, from {it}hanap{/it} goblet, of Germanic origin; akin to Old English {it}hnæpp{/it} bowl
shortdef: a large basket usually with a cover for packing, storing, or transporting articles (such as food or laundry)

dt: {bc}matter or weight (such as spars or rigging) in the upper part of a ship

shortdef: matter or weight (such as spars or rigging) in the upper part of a ship
